entry.et: Middle English, from Old English ǣfnung, from ǣfnian to grow toward evening, from ǣfen evening; akin to Old High German āband evening and perhaps to Greek epi on

def.dt: :the latter part and close of the day and early part of the night
:the period from sunset or the evening meal to bedtime
:suitable for formal or semiformal evening social occasions evening dress evening clothes
:a North American grosbeak (Coccothraustes vespertinus) having conspicuous white wing patches with the male being chiefly yellowish with some black
:the daily evening office of the Anglican liturgy
:any of several dicotyledonous plants of a family (Onagraceae, the evening-primrose family) and especially of the type genus (Oenothera)
:a coarse biennial herb (O. biennis) of North America with yellow flowers that open in the evening
:a bright planet (as Venus) seen especially in the western sky at or after sunset
